SimpleLogin is a open source solution to protect your online identity.

SimpleLogin strives to offer a simple experience for both users and partners/developers.

This Android version is brought to you by SimpleLogin team & Stjin (Stjin.host)
The next time a website asks for your email address, just create a new alias instead of using your real email.
All emails sent to an alias are forwarded to your \"real\" email address without the sender knowing anything.

On your desktop, you can install our browser extension to manage and quickly create aliases on the fly.\n\nOn your smartphone with SimpleLogin installed, whenever you need to register to a website, simply \"share\" the website you are visiting with SimpleLogin to quickly create an alias.

Subscribe to mailing lists, create new online accounts with email alias.

All emails sent to an alias will be forwarded to your personal inbox.

Later on, simply block an alias if it's too spammy.

Just hit \"Reply\" whenever you need to reply to a forwarded email: the reply will come from the alias and your personal mailbox stays hidden.\n\nYou can also send emails to any email address from your alias.

Use alias as your business email.

Save $6/month for each business email created with SimpleLogin.

By the way your company emails are actually aliases.

For security reason and to avoid database leak, all \"forgot password\" requests are taken into account silently without you being informed if a request is successful or not.\n\nSo make sure that you enter the correct email address.
ðŸ’¡Hint: To make it easy to remember for later use, it is a good practice to use the name of the website/service that you plan to register with alias.
Only lowercase letters, dots, numbers, dashes (-) and underscores (_) are currently supported.
To get your API key, you must sign in SimpleLogin by using a browser, then navigate to \"API Key\" tab, create one if not already then copy and paste the key here.
DO NOT change API URL unless you are hosting SimpleLogin with your own server.

A mailbox is just another personal email address. When creating a new alias, you could choose the mailbox that owns this alias, i.e:
- all emails sent to this alias will be forwarded to this mailbox
- from this mailbox, you can reply/send emails from the alias.

When you signed up, a mailbox is automatically created with your account email address.

The mailbox doesn't have to be your email: it can be your friend's email if you want to create aliases for your buddy.
